text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. It just takes me forever to- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -get to sleep. Doctor: When was the last time you took that medication? Patient: The Erlida?

text: Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
